questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18%

 

As per Lund and Browder chart the percentage of burns in this child would be 18%.

 

For the 1-9 years age group, the Lund-Browder chart is divided into the following regions:

 

  1. Head and Neck: 18%
  2. Anterior Trunk: 18%
  3. Posterior Trunk: 18%
  4. Each Arm: 9%
  5. Each Leg: 14%
  6. Perineum: 1%

 

The Lund-Browder chart is a tool used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) of burns in paediatric patients. It is divided into regions that correspond to different percentages of TBSA, and each region is assigned a different percentage based on the age of the patient. The chart takes into account the fact that the proportion of body surface area represented by different body parts changes as a child grows.

 

The chart is divided into three age groups: 0-1 year, 1-9 years, and 9-17 years. Each age group has its own chart with different regions and percentages. The regions are further divided into sub-regions to allow for more accurate estimation of the TBSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9%: For a 6-year-old child, 9% represents the TBSA of each arm. This does not correspond to the head and neck region.

 

Option C. 27%: There is no single region in the Lund-Browder chart for the 1-9 years age group that accounts for 27% of the TBSA. The head and neck alone are 18%.

 

Option D. 36%: This percentage does not correspond to any single region or combination of the head and neck in the Lund-Browder chart for a child of this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

choices.text: Nelson syndrome
Sheehan syndrome
Conn's syndrome

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

 

Explanation:  

 

Nelson syndrome occurs in patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the adrenalectomy, the absence of cortisol feedback leads to increased secretion of ACTH by the pituitary adenoma. This results in:

 

  • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes.
  • Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: Caused by postpartum necrosis of the pituitary gland, leading to hypopituitarism. It presents with failure to lactate, amenorrhea, and hypothyroidism, but not with hyperpigmentation or vision deficits post-adrenalectomy.

 

Option C. Conn's syndrome: Primary hyperaldosteronism, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause hyperpigmentation or vision deficits.

 

Option D. Addison's disease:  Primary adrenal insufficiency presenting with hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH, but it is not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and vision deficits following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, due to the growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lung Abscess

 

The image shows a cavity in the lung with an air-fluid level, which is characteristic of a lung abscess. A lung abscess typically appears as a localized collection of pus within the lung, caused by microbial infection, and is usually associated with an air-fluid level within a thick-walled cavity. This radiologic appearance is a hallmark of a lung abscess and distinguishes it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB (Tuberculosis): Tuberculosis can present with thick-walled cavities but typically does not show a distinct air-fluid level as seen in a lung abscess. TB lesions are often more irregular and do not exhibit the same characteristic air-fluid line.

 

Option C. Fungal Pneumonia: Fungal pneumonia often presents with multiple nodules and may display a "halo sign" (nodules surrounded by ground-glass opacity). It does not typically present as a single cavity with an air-fluid level.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition is characterized by the presence of both air and fluid in the pleural space, often leading to a visible air-fluid level, but the appearance is generally over a larger portion of the hemithorax and not within a lung cavity itself. It appears more diffuse rather than localized like a lung abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lung abscess is identified by a cavity with an air-fluid level on imaging, differentiating it from other pulmonary conditions like TB, fungal infections, and hydropneumothorax.

choices.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

 

The Ans. is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, which is the location known as the flexion point. The flexion point is critical in vacuum-assisted deliveries because it lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle on the baby's head. This point is chosen because pulling on this location causes flexion of the baby's head, facilitating the proper positioning for delivery. Flexion is crucial as it allows the smallest diameter of the baby's head to present, making the delivery process smoother and safer for both the mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.

questions.text: A lesion involving Brodmann area 22 is most likely to result in which of the following deficits? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Receptive aphasia

 

Broadmann’s area 22 corresponds to Wernicke’s area, which is primarily involved in language comprehension. A lesion in this area leads to receptive aphasia, also known as sensory or Wernicke’s aphasia. In receptive aphasia, patients have difficulty understanding spoken language, and their speech may be fluent but lacks meaning or coherence. They can produce words but often speak in nonsensical phrases or sentences that are difficult to understand, indicating a disruption in the processing of language comprehension.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Poor repetition of language: This is associated with conduction aphasia, which occurs due to a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus that connects Broca's and Wernicke's areas. It is characterized by an inability to repeat words or phrases accurately.

 

Option C. Expressive aphasia: This is also known as Broca’s aphasia, resulting from a lesion in Broadmann’s areas 44 and 45. Patients with expressive aphasia have difficulty producing speech, characterized by slow, halting, and effortful speech, but their comprehension remains intact.

 

Option D. Poor naming: Poor naming is typically observed in anomic aphasia, which occurs when the connection between language processing centers is disrupted, but it is not specific to a lesion in Broadmann’s area 22.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in Broadmann’s area 22, known as Wernicke’s area, leads to receptive aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Drug of choice to treat this condition is? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:


The patient presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of bacterial vaginosis (BV). In bacterial vaginosis, the correct treatment is Metronidazole.

 

  • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include:
    1. Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge: The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor.
    2. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5: This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina.
    3. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test): The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide.
    4. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy: Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.

 

Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, and it is typically administered as oral tablets (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Clindamycin: While Clindamycin can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis, it is generally not the first choice. Metronidazole is preferred due to its effectiveness and established use.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is used for a variety of bacterial infections but is not effective for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Azithromycin: This is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and is not used for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:


The drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis is Metronidazole.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Folic acid deficiency in pregnancy may result in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neural tube defects

 

Folic acid is required for DNA synthesis and repair, making it particularly important during periods of rapid cell division and growth, such as pregnancy. Folic acid deficiency during pregnancy is most strongly associated with neural tube defects (NTDs), leading to conditions such as spina bifida and anencephaly.

 

This is why it is recommended that women of childbearing age, and especially those planning a pregnancy, take folic acid supplements to reduce the risk of NTDs. For women with a prior history of NTDs, the recommended dosage of folic acid is 4 mg per day, starting at least 3 months before conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IDA (Iron Deficiency Anemia): While folic acid is involved in the production of red blood cells, iron deficiency is the primary cause of IDA, not folic acid deficiency.

 

Option C. Pernicious anemia: This type of anemia is typically caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12, not folic acid. Pernicious anemia occurs when the body cannot absorb enough B12, which is essential for the production of red blood cells.

 

Option D. Preterm labor, Spontaneous abortions: While folic acid deficiency might contribute to a variety of pregnancy complications, neural tube defects are the most specific and severe consequence directly linked to inadequate folic acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid deficiency during pregnancy is primarily associated with neural tube defects (NTDs). Ensuring adequate intake of folic acid, especially before and during early pregnancy, is crucial for preventing these serious congenital anomalies.

questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mediastinum

 

Extragonadal germ cell tumor is most commonly seen in mediastinum.

 

Extragonadal germinal cell tumors (EGGCTs) are rare tumors that predominantly affect young males.

 

These tumors are particularly significant because they mimic the normal germ cell tumors but appear in unusual locations, making them a critical diagnostic challenge. The prevalence of EGGCTs in the mediastinum indicates the importance of considering this location when evaluating patients with symptoms suggestive of germ cell tumors but without testicular or ovarian masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: While EGGCTs can occur here, they represent only about 5% of cases.

 

Option B. Retroperitoneum: This site accounts for 30-40% of EGGCT cases, making it the second most common site.

 

Option C. Sacrococcygeal region: This is the least common site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of extragonadal germ cell tumor –

 

  • Mediastinum (50-70%)
  • Retroperitoneum (30-40%)
  • Pineal gland (5%)
  • Sacrococcygeal area (less than 5%)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs in leprosy treatment cause hyperpigmentation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used primarily in the treatment of leprosy.
  • One of the notable side effects of clofazimine is skin pigmentation changes, which can manifest as hyperpigmentation.
  • This occurs because clofazimine accumulates in the skin, leading to discoloration.
  • The pigmentation typically appears as a reddish or brownish coloration and can be distressing for patients due to its noticeable cosmetic impact.
  • The pigmentation is long-lasting and may take several months to years to fade after discontinuation of the drug.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is another drug used in the treatment of leprosy, but it does not cause hyperpigmentation. Its side effects include hemolysis and methemoglobinemia, especially in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, including leprosy, but it is not associated with hyperpigmentation. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendonitis.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is an antibiotic used to treat several bacterial infections, including leprosy. It can cause reddish-orange discoloration of bodily fluids like urine, sweat, and tears but does not cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clofazimine is a drug used in leprosy treatment that can cause significant and long-lasting hyperpigmentation of the skin.

questions.text: A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads: superior (or upper) and inferior (or lower). The superior head attaches to the articular disc and the capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This muscle plays a crucial role in the opening of the mouth, protrusion of the mandible, and moving the jaw from side to side. Dysfunction or spasms of this muscle could contribute to jaw locking during yawning. The lateral pterygoid is, therefore, closely associated with the movements and function of the TMJ.

 

All Innervated by CN V3

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle originates from the temporal fossa and inserts onto the coronoid process of the mandible. It's primarily responsible for closing the mouth and is involved in elevating and retracting the mandible. It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ, but it plays a role in jaw movement.

 

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is similar in function to the masseter muscle and helps in elevating the mandible, thus assisting in closing the mouth. It also plays a role in moving the jaw from side to side. However, like the temporalis, it doesn't directly attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option D. Masseter: The masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing). It originates from the zygomatic arch and inserts onto the lateral aspect of the mandibular angle and ramus. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible, assisting in closing the mouth. It does not have an attachment to the articular disc of the TMJ but is important for jaw function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle, particularly its superior head, is uniquely attached to the TMJ's articular disc and plays a pivotal role in jaw movements including mouth opening and lateral movements, making it relevant in cases of jaw locking.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the following radiograph? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis

 

  • The images show the cervical vertebrae where, at the lower cervical spine (C4-C7), there is an anterior slippage of one vertebral body over the one below it. 
  • In the left image, C5 appears to be shifted anteriorly relative to C6. 
  • This slippage is referred to as spondylolisthesis.
  • Spondylolisthesis involves forward displacement of one vertebra over another.
  • Pathology:
    • The pars interarticularis is disrupted on both sides (spondylolysis), separating the posterior neural arch from vertebral body; gap is later filled by fibrous tissue.
    • The vertebral body undergoes anterior dislocation under stress.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Lateral view: Forward shift of the upper part of spinal column on the stable vertebra below; elongation of the arch or defective facets may be seen.
    • Oblique views are needed to clearly demonstrate fracture of pars interarticularis (Beheaded Scottie dog sign)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is a systemic condition characterized by reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), and codfish appearance. It typically appears as generalized radiolucency (bones look "thinner" or "washed out") and potentially vertebral compression fractures. 

 

 

Option C. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect or fracture at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. It is difficult to definitively diagnose spondylolysis on a plain lateral cervical X-ray without oblique views or a CT.  

 

 

Option D. Discitis. This is an or infection of the intervertebral disc and adjacent vertebral bodies. Radiographically, it would typically show disc space narrowing. This is not the primary finding observed in these images. Discitis is a serious but uncommon infection or inflammation of the intervertebral disc space. Radiographic findings include the narrowing of disc space, irregular endplates, and sometimes erosions or sclerosis of the vertebral bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the given question shows spondylolisthesis of C6 vertebra over C7 vertebra.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient complains of a nodular lesion near the limbus as shown, with mild discomfort that resolves after treatment with the use of a topical drug. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Episcleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Episcleritis is an inflammatory condition affecting the episclera, the layer of tissue lying between the conjunctiva and the sclera. It often presents with a red, nodular lesion near the limbus that causes mild discomfort and responds well to topical treatment, such as phenylephrine, which is a vasoconstrictor. Phenylephrine helps blanch the inflamed vessels, reducing symptoms and improving the appearance of the lesion. Episcleritis is often associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis: Scleritis involves deeper inflammation of the sclera and is much more painful compared to episcleritis. It does not resolve with topical treatment alone and often requires systemic therapy. This does not match the scenario of mild discomfort and resolution with topical drugs.

 

Option C. Pinguecula and Dry Eye: Pinguecula is a yellowish, elastotic degeneration of the conjunctiva that typically appears as a quiet, non-inflamed lesion. It does not cause significant discomfort or redness, making this an unlikely diagnosis in the presence of nodular inflammation.

 

 

Option D. Pterygium and Astigmatism: Pterygium is characterized by a wing-shaped growth of conjunctiva that extends onto the cornea, causing astigmatism. Since the lesion in question does not encroach onto the cornea, pterygium is not a suitable diagnosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Episcleritis presents as a mildly uncomfortable, nodular lesion near the limbus that responds to topical treatment, such as phenylephrine, and is often associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a woman with atrophic vaginitis with complaints of itching? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical estrogen

 

Explanation

 

Topical estrogen:

 

  • Atrophic vaginitis, also known as vaginal atrophy, is a condition that commonly affects postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels. It leads to symptoms such as vaginal dryness, itching, and discomfort.
  • Local estrogen preparations are preferred over systemic hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the treatment of postmenopausal vaginal atrophy. This is because local treatments directly target the affected area and have fewer systemic side effects.
  • The use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally, applied each day for 1 to 2 weeks, generally provides symptomatic relief for women experiencing atrophic vaginitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids: Steroids are not the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis. They do not address the underlying cause, which is the lack of estrogen.

 

Option C. Antihistamines only: Antihistamines may provide temporary relief from itching but do not treat the underlying cause of atrophic vaginitis, which is estrogen deficiency.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as topical estrogen is the recommended treatment for atrophic vaginitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, particularly in postmenopausal women, is the application of topical estrogen to provide symptomatic relief and address the underlying estrogen deficiency.

 

Ref: Page 1469, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecology

questions.text: Which of the following is the pattern of inheritance with the pedigree chart provided in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial inheritance

 

The pedigree chart provided in the image demonstrates a pattern of inheritance where an affected female passes the trait or disease to all of her offspring, regardless of their gender. Additionally, the affected males do not pass the trait to any of their offspring. This pattern is characteristic of mitochondrial inheritance, also known as maternal inheritance.

 

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother because mitochondria in the sperm are typically not involved in fertilization. Therefore, any mutations in mitochondrial DNA will be passed from an affected mother to all of her children. However, because males do not contribute mitochondria to their offspring, they do not pass on mitochondrial diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance typically requires both parents to carry one copy of the mutated gene, and it affects both males and females equally. The pattern in the pedigree, where all children of an affected female are affected, does not fit an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant inheritance usually involves a 50% chance of passing the mutated gene from an affected parent to each child, regardless of gender. The pedigree showing all offspring of an affected female being affected, while none of the offspring of an affected male are affected, does not fit this pattern.

 

Option C. X-linked recessive: X-linked recessive inheritance usually affects males more frequently, as they have only one X chromosome. Affected males would pass the mutated gene to all of their daughters (who would be carriers) but none of their sons. This pattern does not match the pedigree chart provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of a trait from an affected mother to all of her offspring, while affected males do not pass the trait to their children. This unique pattern is due to the inheritance of mitochondrial DNA, which is maternally inherited.

 

Example of Maternal/ mitochondrial inheritance diseases: Leber's Optic Neuropathy, MELAS Syndrome (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like manifestation).

questions.text: Which absorbs least water? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cellulose

 

Cellulose is an insoluble fiber that does not absorb water to a significant extent. It remains relatively dry when exposed to water and does not become gummy. Cellulose is known for its role in providing structure to plant cell walls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucilage: Mucilage is a type of soluble fiber that absorbs water and becomes gummy when mixed with it. It has the capacity to absorb a significant amount of water and is often used in various applications due to its water-absorbing properties.

 

Option C. Gums: Gums, such as guar gum and xanthan gum, are water-soluble fibers that can absorb water and form a gel-like consistency. They have the ability to absorb moderate amounts of water.

 

Option D. Pectins: Pectins are another type of water-soluble fiber found in plant cells. When pectins come into contact with water, they form a gel-like substance and can absorb a considerable amount of water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cellulose:

 

  • Most abundant natural polysaccharide
  • Unbranched                                     
  • Made up of β–Glucose residues
  • Acts as fibres in the diet (as β-bonds cannot be easily broken in body)

 

Ref - Lehninger 6th ed pg 257

choices.text: Anterior wall of the left ventricle
Inferior surface of the right ventricle

questions.text: A patient with a recent MI underwent coronary angiography, which revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery. The infarction is likely to be present in which of the following regions of the heart? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior wall of the left ventricle

 

Explanation:

 

The patient with recent myocardial infarction (MI), who underwent coronary angiography, revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery or LAD).

 

The LAD is a branch of the left coronary artery and is commonly referred to as the "widow's artery" due to its high incidence of involvement in angina and MI. The LAD runs along the anterior side of the heart and supplies the apex of the ventricle. The left coronary artery is the main artery supplying the left ventricle. Therefore, a block in the LAD would most likely result in an infarction in the anterior wall of the left ventricle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior part of interventricular septum: Incorrect. The posterior part of the interventricular septum is primarily supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which is usually a branch of the right coronary artery (RCA) or sometimes the left circumflex artery (LCX).

 

Option C. Lateral part of the heart: Incorrect. The lateral part of the heart is mainly supplied by the left circumflex artery (LCX), another branch of the left coronary artery.

 

Option D. Inferior surface of the right ventricle: Incorrect. The inferior surface of the right ventricle is supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA) and its branches, such as the marginal branch and the posterior descending artery (PDA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle, and a block in this artery can lead to an infarction in this region of the heart.

questions.text:
Korsakoff psychosis is true except? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amnesia
  2. Confabulation
  3. Ophthalmoplegia
  4. Ataxia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

Korsakoff psychosis is a chronic neurological condition often associated with long-term alcohol abuse leading to vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency. The condition is characterized by severe memory issues, particularly anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and confabulation (fabrication of memories to fill in gaps in recollection). Patients may also experience retrograde amnesia (loss of pre-existing memories).

 

  • Amnesia: This is a hallmark symptom of Korsakoff psychosis. Patients have significant difficulty forming new memories and may lose some of their older memories.
  • Confabulation: Another key feature, where patients unknowingly create false memories to fill in the gaps of their amnesia. These fabricated memories are often a mix of true events and imagination but are presented by the patient as genuine recollections.

 

Other options:

 

  • Ophthalmoplegia: This condition, characterized by paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles, is not a feature of Korsakoff psychosis but rather of Wernicke's encephalopathy, the acute phase that can precede Korsakoff syndrome if left untreated.
  • Ataxia: Like ophthalmoplegia, ataxia (lack of voluntary coordination of muscle movements) is a symptom of Wernicke's encephalopathy rather than Korsakoff psychosis. Ataxia affects the patient's gait and movement, but it is not present in the chronic Korsakoff stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff psychosis is primarily characterized by amnesia and confabulation, not by ophthalmoplegia or ataxia, which are associated with the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy phase of thiamine deficiency

questions.text: A 65-year-old PLHIV patient came with cough, fever, and pneumonia. Biopsy shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV

 

In the biopsy image, the characteristic feature to note is the presence of inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and the cytoplasm of the cell, giving an appearance often described as "owl eye." This is a hallmark of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV can cause severe infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as patients living with HIV (PLHIV). The virus leads to the formation of large cells with nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella: Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause pneumonia, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not produce the distinctive "owl eye" inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

 

Option C. EBV: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is known for causing infectious mononucleosis and is associated with various lymphoproliferative disorders, but there is no inclusion bodies in the cells.

 

Option D. HSV2: Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2) can cause various infections, including pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, but it does not produce the specific "owl eye" inclusions seen in CMV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of "owl eye" inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of cells in a biopsy is indicative of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those living with HIV.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a mass in the right kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal cell carcinoma        

 

Explanation:

 

The case of an elderly man with a heterogeneous large renal mass in the CECT image suggests renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC often appears as a solid renal mass with areas of necrosis or hemorrhage that cause the heterogeneity in density seen on CT images. This type of cancer is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults and can present with various imaging appearances, but a large, irregular, and heterogeneous mass is highly suggestive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal angiomyolipoma: Typically appears as a well-circumscribed mass with a significant fat component, which should show negative Hounsfield units (HU) on CT, which is not evident in the presented image.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Generally presents as a well-circumscribed, homogenous mass with a central scar. It does not typically appear as heterogeneous as RCC.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure with very well-defined borders and no solid components, which does not match the characteristics of the mass show

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient came with pain in the abdomen and on further imaging the following is obtained. What is the best management option for this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureteroscopic removal

 

The given X-ray image shows a left lower/distal ureteric stone. Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for ureteric stones, specifically those present in the distal ureter.

 

  • This procedure involves passing a small scope directly into the ureter (usually via the bladder) to visualize the stone. Once the stone is located, it can be fragmented (usually with a laser) and the pieces can be removed.
  • Ureteroscopic removal is often preferred for stones located in the distal ureter, especially if they are below 6 mm in size. The advantage of this method is direct visualization and removal of the stone.
  • Potential complications can include ureteric injury, perforation, and subsequent stricture formation, although these are relatively rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy):

 

  • PCNL is an invasive procedure where a tract is created from the skin directly into the kidney. Through this tract, instruments can be inserted to fragment and extract stones.
  • This approach is most commonly used for large renal stones or when other treatments have failed. It's generally not the first-line treatment for a distal ureteric stone.

 

Option B. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy):

 

  • ESWL uses shock waves generated outside the body to fragment stones inside the urinary tract. The fragmented stone pieces can then pass out with urine.
  • ESWL is most suitable for small to medium-sized stones located in the kidney or upper ureter. It is less effective for distal ureteric stones compared to ureteroscopic removal.

 

Option D. Reassurance:

 

  • Some small stones, especially those in the lower ureter, might pass spontaneously. In such cases, if the stone isn't causing obstruction, infection, or severe pain, the patient might be advised to drink plenty of water and wait to see if the stone passes on its own.
  • Pain management and periodic follow-ups would be essential. However, for symptomatic stones, active removal is often preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For symptomatic distal ureteric stones, ureteroscopic removal is typically the best management option due to its effectiveness and minimal invasiveness.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Class II

 

The image shows a Mallampati class II airway.

 

  • The Mallampati classification, sometimes referred to as the Mallampati score or Mallampati test, is a system used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation. It correlates the visibility of the base of the uvula, faucial pillars, and the soft palate with the ease of laryngeal visualization and intubation.
  • Class I: Hard palate, Soft palate, entire uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible.
  • Class II: Hard palate, Soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.
  • Class III: Only hard palate and  soft palate is visible.
  • Class IV: Only hard palate is visible.

 

 

The primary purpose of the Mallampati classification is to assess the potential difficulty of intubation in patients prior to surgery or in any other situation requiring airway management. A higher Mallampati score generally indicates a more challenging intubation. Anesthesiologists and surgeons use the Mallampati classification as a component of the preoperative airway assessment. This assessment helps them to be prepared for potential airway challenges during surgery and determine if specialized equipment or techniques might be necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Class I: This classification is incorrect as the image does not show all the structures visible in Class I, such as the uvula and pillars.

 

Option C. Class IV: This classification is incorrect because the image does not show only the hard palate, which would be indicative of Class IV.

 

Option D. Class III: This classification is incorrect as the image shows more structures than what would be visible in Class III, where only the soft palate is visible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is a useful tool for predicting the difficulty of intubation, with higher classes indicating more challenging airways. The image provided corresponds to Mallampati class II, where the soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The given image shows the life cycle of the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

 

The herpes virus is a linear double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. The envelope has glycoprotein spikes.

 

Steps of HSV replication:

 

  • The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane
  • Viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore.
  • Transcription of immediate-early genes - alpha-Proteins
  • Transcription of late genes produces y-proteins which consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.
  • Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids.
  • Viral particles which are enveloped, collect in the endoplasmic reticulum
  • They are transported to cell surface by a vesicular movement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is spherical, enveloped virus with an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core which encloses the ribonucleoproteins. It consists of two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

 

HIV virus life cycle.

 

 

Option C. The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus. It has an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. It contains two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand is incomplete resulting in partially double stranded and partially single-stranded DNA.

 

 

Option D. Corona viruses: The genome of coronaviruses is made up of positive sense, unsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronaviruses are enclosed RNA viruses. They feature surface projections in the form of petals. In the cytoplasm, coronavirus nucleocapsids grow and mature by budding into cytoplasmic vesicles. The structure and life cycle of coronaviruses are depicted in the figures below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

choices.text: b, d and e only
c and e only
a and c only
Only e is correct

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about drug resistant malaria: (AIIMS May 2019)

 

  1. It is not present in India.
  2. Quinine with clindamycin or doxycycline is still effective treatment.
  3. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective.
  4. Artemether with lumefantrine is useful.
  5. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is not useful due to high risk of recrudescence.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. b, d and e only

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is now the most common cause of malaria as well as most common cause of drug resistant malaria in India (Option a is false)
  • DOC for multiple drug resistant P falciparum is artemisinin compounds, but they are short acting. The short action is responsible for recrudescence when used as monotherapy in malaria. So they are combined with long acting drugs (known as ACT; Artemisinin based Combination Therapy) like 
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North-Eastern states.
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine/Pyrimethamine: DOC all over India except NE states.
  • Artemisinin’s are contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy; but can be given in second and third trimester.
  • So, if drug resistant malaria occurs in 1st trimester of pregnancy, DOC is Quinine. To reduce its toxicity, we commonly add clindamycin (in pregnancy and children) or doxycycline (in other patients).
  • Chloroquine is not effective in drug resistant malaria. So artesunate (not Chloroquine) is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (Option c)  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is not present in India. False. Drug-resistant malaria is present in India. Plasmodium falciparum, known for drug resistance, is a common cause of malaria in India.

 

Option C. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective. False. Chloroquine is not effective in drug-resistant malaria. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug-resistant malaria in India is effectively treated with ACTs like Artemether with lumefantrine. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is avoided due to the risk of recrudescence.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/876-877

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. It consists of five components: cyanosis, retractions, grunting, air entry, and respiratory rate (RR). Each component is scored from 0 to 2, with a total possible score of 10. Here's the breakdown for the given case:

 

 

Summing up the scores:


1 (cyanosis) + 1 (retractions) + 2 (grunting) + 2 (air entry) + 0 (RR) = 6

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer
Increases risk of osteoporosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

questions.text: A patient with nasal bleeding was found to have nasal polyps; histopathology post-excision is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image features large sporangia containing numerous spores, typical of Rhinosporidiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma: Caused by Klebsiella, characterized by Mikulicz cells, not seen here.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumor that would show proliferating blood vessels.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: Fungal infection, but its histology typically shows spherules, not sporangia with spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis is characterized by its histopathology featuring large sporangia with spores, differentiating it from other nasal lesions such as Rhinoscleroma, Hemangioma, and Coccidioidomycosis.

questions.text: Identify the site marked in given barium follow-through of small intestine.(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Jejunum

 

  • Jejunum identification: Jejunum has valves of Kerkring (Valvulae conniventes)
  • Complete mucosal folds extending through lumen of jejunum: Feathery appearance of jejunum
  • Ileum identification: Featureless loops - smooth bowel loop without any folds
  • Colon identification: Incomplete mucosal folds called as haustrations
  • For Normal Bowel Rotation: D-J flexure should be towards the left of midline and on the same plane as duodenal bulb which is L1 / transpyloric plane (if not: sign of malrotation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ileum: Characterized by featureless loops with smooth bowel loops without any folds, which are not seen in the marked area.

 

Option C. Colon: Identified by incomplete mucosal folds called haustrations, which are different from the continuous folds seen in the jejunum.

 

Option D. Duodenum: Located proximal to the jejunum and has a different radiographic appearance, typically not showing the extensive mucosal folds of the jejunum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The jejunum can be identified in imaging by the presence of valvulae conniventes creating a feathery appearance, distinguishing it from the ileum and colon.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has come with history of lower back pain and stiffness since 3 months. His ESR and CRP levels are raised. He has mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion is 3 cms. History of red eye is also there. The most likely diagnosis from amongst the following would be:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Males are affected more frequently than females.
    • Age of onset is between 15-25 years.
    • The initial symptom is usually dull pain, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, accompanied by low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis) occurring in 30%.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
  • Etiology:
    • HLA B27 positive in more than 90 % cases
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • Bamboo spine (bony ankyloses)
    • Squaring of vertebrae
    • Inter-spinous ligament calcification: dagger sign
    • Facet calcification of joints + inter spinous ligament Trolley Track Sign
    • Sclerosed vertebral edges: romanus sign

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity.

 

 

The diagnostic histological feature is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. It either occurs in one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic).

 

 

Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal. Increased marker of bone formation (e.g. S. alkaline phosphatase and S. osteocalcin). Increased markers of bone resorption. X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening, coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen.

 

 

Option B. Healed TB. The remineralization of the vertebral body, sharpening of disc margins, reduction of pre-/paravertebral shadows, and osseous/fibro-osseous fusion are signs of healing on X-rays but are unreliable. The remineralization can be appreciated after 2-3 months of ATT. Complete resolution of pre-/paravertebral collections, marrow edema of vertebra, and its replacement by fat/calcification on contrast MRI are observed with healing of spine TB. 

 

 

Serial radiographs showing progression of bony healing and complete resolution of cold abscess

 

Option C. DISH. Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spondyloarthropathy, also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis. It is a non-inflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses. The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankyloses occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected. In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine. The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine. Morning stiffness is also noticed in around 2/3rd of patients. Increased incidence of dysphagia is also reported in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Presence of lower back pain and stiffness since months, raised levels of ESR and CRP, mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion, with history of red eye are suggestive of presence of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Audiogram of a patient is given. Find the sign that can be seen in the same case. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwartz sign

 

The audiogram shows a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz, known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis. Otosclerosis is a condition where abnormal bone growth occurs in the middle ear, particularly affecting the stapes bone, leading to conductive hearing loss.

 

Schwartz sign is associated with otosclerosis and refers to a reddish hue seen behind the intact tympanic membrane near the oval window due to increased vascularity from active otosclerotic processes. It is a contraindication for stapes surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balance sign: This sign is unrelated to otosclerosis. Balance sign generally refers to signs related to balance issues and is not associated with hearing loss patterns on an audiogram.

 

Option B. Hennebert sign: Hennebert sign is a false positive fistula test that does not relate to otosclerosis. It is more commonly associated with conditions like Ménière's disease or syphilis affecting the inner ear.

 

Option D. Hitzelberger sign: This sign is seen in acoustic neuroma and involves hypesthesia of the posterior wall of the external auditory canal. It is not connected with otosclerosis or the Carhart's notch observed in the audiogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz on an audiogram is a specific finding in otosclerosis, and Schwartz sign, a reddish hue behind the tympanic membrane, is an associated clinical sign indicating active otosclerotic processes.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of scrotal exploration is shown. Identify the pathology. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Testicular torsion

 

The correct answer is Testicular torsion. Testicular torsion occurs when the spermatic cord, which supplies blood to the testicle, becomes twisted, cutting off the blood supply. This condition presents with acute scrotal pain and is a surgical emergency. The intra-operative image shows a discolored and non-viable testis, which is characteristic of testicular torsion. Exploration in such cases is mandatory to assess the viability of the testis and to perform detorsion or orchiectomy if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torsion of testicular appendage: Torsion of the testicular appendage, a small vestigial remnant located at the superior pole of the testis, is a self-limiting condition and does not usually necessitate surgical exploration. The testis in such cases remains normal, and the main feature is localized pain without the full testicular involvement seen in the provided image.

 

Option C. Torsion of both: It is highly unlikely for both the testis and the appendage to undergo torsion simultaneously as they are separate anatomical structures. Thus, the option of torsion of both is not realistic.

 

Option D. Testicular hematoma: A testicular hematoma would present as swelling due to bleeding within the testicular parenchyma or surrounding tissue, often following trauma. The appearance would not match the twisted and non-viable look of the testis shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testicular torsion presents as acute testicular pain and requires urgent surgical intervention. The characteristic appearance on exploration includes a discolored, possibly non-viable testis due to the loss of blood supply.

questions.text: In a patient who has undergone gastrectomy, vitamin supplementation required is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vit B12

 

After a gastrectomy, the patient's stomach no longer has parietal cells, which are responsible for secreting intrinsic factor. The intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of Vitamin B12 in the small intestine. Without intrinsic factor, Vitamin B12 cannot be effectively absorbed, leading to a deficiency. This is why patients who have undergone a gastrectomy require supplemental Vitamin B12 to prevent deficiency, which can lead to conditions such as pernicious anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vit C: Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, wound healing, and as an antioxidant. However, its absorption is not dependent on the stomach or intrinsic factor, so a gastrectomy patient does not necessarily need supplemental Vitamin C.

 

Option B. Vit D: Vitamin D is important for calcium absorption and bone health, but its absorption is primarily related to the function of the liver and kidneys, not the stomach. Thus, a gastrectomy patient does not require supplemental Vitamin D specifically due to the surgery.

 

Option D. Vit A: Vitamin A is crucial for vision, immune function, and skin health. Its absorption is fat-dependent and occurs in the small intestine. A gastrectomy does not directly impact Vitamin A absorption, so supplementation is not typically necessary unless there is another underlying deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients who have undergone a gastrectomy require supplemental Vitamin B12 due to the loss of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for the absorption of this vitamin

questions.text: All of the following can be used in first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate:
    • This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods.
  • Medical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Mifepristone + misoprostol: A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Surgical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Manual vacuum aspiration: This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester.
    • Dilatation and curettage: Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone + misoprostol: Mifepristone + misoprostol is a commonly used combination for medical termination in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Manual vacuum aspiration: Manual vacuum aspiration is a standard procedure for first-trimester abortion.

 

Option C. Dilatation and evacuation: Dilatation and evacuation is another method used in the first trimester to terminate a pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is not used for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg364,369, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg203

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain. During the medical examination, it is discovered that the patient has prostate cancer. The medical team suspects that the cancer may have spread to the lumbar vertebrae. What is the likely route of spread for prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostatic venous plexus

 

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae is primarily through the prostatic venous plexus or Bateson plexus. Tumor cells spread to the spine and proximal long bones via Bateson's venous plexus, which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.
  • The prostatic venous plexus (or Bateson plexus) is a network of veins surrounding the prostate.
  • The prostatic venous plexus has connections to the internal vertebral venous plexuses.
  • Because of this unique venous anatomy, tumor cells from the prostate can enter the venous system and bypass the usual portal and caval routes, spreading directly to the spine, specifically the lumbar vertebrae.
  • This is the most common route for metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans coelomic spread: Trans coelomic spread refers to the dissemination of malignant cells across body cavities, such as the pleural, peritoneal, or pericardial spaces. This method of spread is most commonly seen with primary cancers of the ovary, stomach, and colon. In the context of prostate cancer, trans coelomic spread is not a typical route to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Option C. Inferior vesical vein: The inferior vesical vein drains the urinary bladder. While there are venous communications between the prostatic plexus and the vesical veins, the direct spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae through the inferior vesical vein alone is less common than through the prostatic venous plexus.

 

Option D. Internal iliac vein: The internal iliac vein drains blood from the pelvis and perineum. While prostate cancer can spread through the internal iliac vein as part of its venous drainage, this route is not the primary pathway to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer primarily spreads to the lumbar vertebrae through the prostatic venous plexus (Bateson plexus), which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.

choices.text: Anterior division of middle cerebral artery
Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery
Posterior division of middle cerebral artery

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

 

The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.

 

The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum. Once inside, it divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery ascends vertically to supply the dura and the calvaria. Importantly, this artery courses in close proximity to the pterion. A blow to the pterion can fracture the thin bone here and rupture this artery, leading to an epidural hematoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

option A. Anterior division of middle cerebral artery: This artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes of the brain. After the middle cerebral artery (MCA) exits the lateral sulcus, it bifurcates into its anterior and posterior divisions. However, the MCA and its divisions run deep within the brain, within the depths of the lateral sulcus and over the insular cortex. While they are critical for brain function, they don't have a direct relationship to the pterion on the external surface of the skull.

 

Option C. Posterior division of middle cerebral artery: Similar to the anterior division, the posterior division of the middle cerebral artery runs deep within the brain and does not have a direct relationship to the pterion.

 

Option D. Stem of middle meningeal artery: The stem of the middle meningeal artery is the segment between its origin (from the maxillary artery) and its bifurcation into anterior and posterior divisions. As it enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum, the stem is somewhat close to the pterion but it's the anterior division that actually courses near the pterion on the inner surface of the skull.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak. This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut:  Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D. The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:


The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis is associated with which type of cancer? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis, also known as the Chinese liver fluke, is a parasitic worm that infects the bile ducts of the liver. Chronic infection with Clonorchis sinensis is a well-known risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma, which is a type of cancer that occurs in the bile ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular cancer: This is commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B and C infections, cirrhosis, and aflatoxin exposure, not typically with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option C. Gastric cancer: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, dietary factors, and genetic predisposition, not with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option D. Urinary bladder cancer: Often linked to smoking, occupational exposures, and Schistosoma haematobium infection (another type of parasitic worm), not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opisthorchis viverrini is the new name of Clonorchis sinensis. It is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Humans acquire the infection by eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish containing the metacercariae (infective stage).

 

Chronic infection leads to:

 

  • Inflammation
  • Hyperplasia of the biliary epithelium
  • Fibrosis
  • Malignant transformation → Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma):

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology:
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% malignant transformation. This is incorrect. Pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.

 

Option C. Ground glass opacity is diagnostic. This is incorrect. Ground glass opacity of the bone is seen in fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy is the treatment. This is incorrect. The mainstay of treatment of GCT is curettage and stripping of the cavity. More aggressive tumors are treated by excision and bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with recurrent chalazion, which cancer is suspected?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Sebaceous cell carcinoma is a malignancy of the sebaceous glands, which can present as recurrent chalazion.

 

Chalazion is an inflammation of the meibomian glands, which are modified sebaceous glands located in the eyelids.

 

While chalazion is typically a benign condition, its recurrence, particularly in elderly patients, can be indicative of underlying sebaceous cell carcinoma.

 

This carcinoma is notorious for masquerading as benign eyelid lesions, thus a history of recurrent chalazion warrants further investigation to rule out this malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This is the second most common type of eyelid cancer, but it does not typically present as recurrent chalazion. It more often presents as a chronic, non-healing ulcerative lesion.

 

Option C. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common eyelid cancer but usually presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectasia rather than as recurrent chalazion.

 

Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma: This vascular tumor is associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV/AIDS. It typically presents as red or purple macules, plaques, or nodules, not as recurrent chalazion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent chalazion should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, especially in elderly patients, as this malignancy can mimic benign eyelid lesions.
